title: The Array Quest
subtitle: Storing Multiple Treasures
description:
# The Treasure Collection

You've been collecting treasures on your adventure, but carrying them one at a time is inefficient! It's time to learn about **arrays** - containers that can hold multiple items of the same type.

## What is an Array?

An array in C# is a collection of items of the same type stored in a specific order. Think of it like a backpack that can hold many treasures!

```csharp
string[] treasures = { "gold coin", "ruby", "magic scroll" };
```

**Key concepts:**
- Arrays are created with type followed by `[]`
- Items are enclosed in curly braces `{ }`
- Items are separated by commas `,`
- All items must be the same type
- Items maintain their order
- Statements end with semicolons `;`

## Accessing Array Items

Each item in an array has an **index** (position number), starting from 0:

```csharp
string[] treasures = { "gold coin", "ruby", "magic scroll" };
Console.WriteLine(treasures[0]);  // Prints: gold coin
Console.WriteLine(treasures[1]);  // Prints: ruby
Console.WriteLine(treasures[2]);  // Prints: magic scroll
```

## Your Quest

1. Create an array called `inventory` with these items: `"sword"`, `"shield"`, `"potion"`
2. Print the **first item** in the array (the sword)
3. Print the **third item** in the array (the potion)
4. Print the **entire array** using a loop or string.Join
hints: Arrays use curly braces { } and items are separated by commas
Remember: array indices start at 0, not 1! So the first item is inventory[0]
The third item is at index 2 (0, 1, 2)
You can print the whole array with string.Join(", ", inventory)
Make sure to use quotation marks around the string items and semicolons at the end of statements
